CITY OF PAPILLION CHLORINE LEAK INVESTIGATION AND STOPPAGE



GENERAL:

The goal of this manual is to minimize an operator's risk of chlorine exposure. The best action an operator can do is to remove himself from the area of the leak and call for help. The section will outline the proper procedure for investigating a chlorine leak as well as the necessary steps to stop the leak. Leak investigation and or repair should only be done by trained operators. Operators first aware of the leak should evaluate the situation to see if action can be taken to minimize the leak from a safe distance.



SAFETY EQUIPMENT:

SCBA (self-contained breathing apparatus) and level "A" protective suit for leaks with unknown concentrations or concentrations 40 ppm. Full back up of trained personnel required, full backup will require a fire department hazmat team to be present and will be in command of the scene.



Chlorine concentrations may vary within a room, use additional protection when in doubt.



A portable leak detector should also be used.



LEAK INVESTIGATION:

All known or possible leaks shall be investigated through the use of aqua ammonia vapor. A plastic squeeze bottle containing commercial 26 degree Baume aqua ammonia will be used to direct ammonia vapor towards the suspected leak. Care must be taken to avoid getting any of the liquid portion of the aqua ammonia on piping, the liquid should not come in contact with brass or copper. If a leak is found, actions need to be taken to isolate the leak until repairs are made.



LEAK STOPPAGE OR REPAIR:

Chlorine Containers: The type of chlorine cylinders that the City of Papillion water treatment plant uses are one ton chlorine cylinders. We have the necessary emergency kits to stop leaks in this type of cylinder. Included with the kits are instruction manuals describing how to properly use the kits. 



The City of Papillion does not own any of the cylinders in which the chlorine is shipped. If a leak occurs on one of these cy

linders the operator should use the required kit to repair the leaking cylinder then after the leak has been stopped the owners of the cylinder shall be contacted for disposal. 



Chlorine Equipment and Piping: If there is a leak on chlorine piping or the chlorine equipment, the repairs should be made with the knowledge and approval of the supervisor.



LEAK CLASSIFICATION:

All leaks shall be tested and repaired according to the requirements of this manual. The supervisor or another trained operator will assist another trained operator in leak classification. Leak areas should not be entered unless there is another trained and equipped operator present. Each leak will be classified into one of three categories, the severity of the leak will determine the class. The three classes are as follows:

Class 1: No alert. The chlorine leak in minor (less than 40 ppm) and can be brought under control.

Class 2: Alert status. The chlorine leak has the potential to become uncontrollable. In its present state the chlorine leak can be controlled. Concentration is unknown or more than 40 ppm. Personnel are being safely removed from the danger area.

Class 3: Evacuation. The chlorine leak is not controllable and may affect City of Papillion personnel or surrounding community.



RESPONSE TO ALARMS:

The response to a chlorine alarm is to first make sure that all personnel are safe. Leak repairs shall be made according to the requirements of this manual. All unplanned leaks shall be reported to the plant supervisor as soon as possible. The responses shall be first to protect the safety of all person, secondly the leak should be limited and/or vented from a safe distance as possible. The leak area shall not be entered for the purpose of investigation or repair unless instructed by your supervisor.



Class 1: During normal and non- working hours the operators under direct supervision of the supervisor shall normally take actions necessary to safely bring the leak under control an

d repair the leak.

Class 2: During normal working hours the operators under direct supervision of the supervisor shall normally take actions necessary to try and bring the leak under control from a remote area and repair the leak after the chlorine concentration drops below 40 ppm or lower. Other operators shall be informed a Class 2 leak has occurred and should evacuate or be prepared to evacuate on a moment's notice. 

During non-working hours the supervisor will be notified of the Class 2 leak and make the appropriate calls for assistance and actions that need to be taken.

Class 3: During normal working hours the operators and or their supervisor shall call 911 then take immediate action (within a safe distance) to limit the leak as much as possible. Other operators shall be informed that a Class 3 leak had occurred. They shall evacuate their area and go to the predetermined meeting point, such as an interior room if it is safe to do so or the parking lot in a position that is upwind from the leak. 

During non-working hours the supervisor shall call 911 and then take immediate actions (within safe distance) to limit the leak as much as possible and assist with emergency response procedures.



RESIDENCES:

Shelter: The normal method of handling any leak that may threaten the surrounding community will be to notify the fire and police departments and advise all residents within ? mile of the affected area be sheltered. This mean that all windows shall be closed and cent systems shut down and wait for further information.

Evacuation: If a leak of massive nature occurs and shelter would not provide adequate protection, the evacuation of the surrounding community may be necessary. Coordination with the fire and police departments is essential if evacuation becomes necessary.



OUTSIDE ASSISTANCE:

If a Class 3 leak occurs, outside assistance is required. The operator or supervisor will call the following agencies in the order listed. CHLOREP is a chlorine emerge

ncy program, coordinated by the chlorine institute, designed to assist chlorine users in responding to chlorine emergencies in the U.S. and Canada. It operates on a 24 hour, 7 day a week basis. CHLOREP can be reached through CHEMTREC phone number.

1.    Fire and police department - 911 

2.    CHEMTREC (24 hour emergency phone number) - 800.424.9300

3.    DPC Industries (Local Reaction Team) - 402.293.1185

Certain information necessary when making these calls are employee's name, company name, nature of the problem, assistance required, phone number, address, and any other pertinent information.



ALL CLEAR NOTIFICATION:

Once the emergency has been eliminated the Chlorine Emergency Response Coordinator will notify all those affected by the emergency.



HOT WORK:

No hot work to this date has ever been done or in the near future within the facility or on the facility property.

68.48                Maximum intended inventory and safe upper and lower operation parameters

In the summer time we try to keep 5 full cylinders on hand as cannot predict if there will be a shortage or a manmade problem.  This would be 4 of them on scales and 1 on the floor.

The safe upper and lower operating parameters that we use are the lower .5 PPM and upper is 1.5 PPM for the system and this is tested daily from the clear well at plant and the 2 reservoirs in town as the water from plant goes to them.



68.52 (a)       Chlorine detection system, changing cylinders.

 A .There 2 detection's units in the storage room and the mechanical room, and a hand held unit at the plant.

We use a rag with ammonia on it hold next to sensor this will make the unit go off and also kick in the scrubber, we do this quarterly.   

B.  Changing cylinders are done by shutting the valve off on the tank and valve on the effluent line remove the unit from tank put the brass cap on the cylinder valve and then put

the main cover over the valve then removed the empty tank and replace with a full tank, remove the outer cap covering the main valve then before removing the brass cap on the main valve make sure the valve is off, then remove the brass cap and install the unit with 2 new lead washers on the tank making sure sung then crack the main valve on cylinder, then use the ammonia puffer to make sure no leak if there is it will show a white smoke if none open tank valve 1 full turn and open effluent valve and put back in service.



68.52 (b) Emergency Shut Down Procedure

A. If a chlorine gas leak is present in the chlorine storage area, first thing is to put on your S.C.B.A (self-contained breathing apparatus) then you may enter the room and shut the valve on the chlorine cylinder or cylinders that have the leak. Allow the room to air out with the help of the exhaust fan after the room is safe of all gas you will now be able to determine what the cause of the leak was and make the proper repairs. All parts are located on the mezzanine which is the area above the chemical rooms.

B. If there is a chlorine gas leak present in the control room first you need to shut off the supply from the tank and those are located in the storage room on the south side of the tanks labeled 1,2,3,4. After the chlorine supply is shut off you must shut off the water supply which is located behind the chlorine scrubber unit.  Allow the room to be properly vented before entry, an S.C.B.A may be needed for entry. Now you will be able to diagnose the problem and make repairs where needed.

68.52 (b) (6) Shut Down and Start Up of CL2 system

A. Shutoff effluent valves in the storage room then crack the lines after the valve to allow air to travel through the lined to ensure that all chlorine gas has been removed. You should be able to see air bubbles going through the site glass tubes. After blowing out the gas you must then turn off the water supply located behind the chlorine scrubber.

B. You will

now be able to take the injection apart as instructed in the book and replace all necessary parts. Once all parts are replaced make a note of what was used so new parts can be ordered to ensure we always have what we need in stock.  

C. Once all repairs have been made you will now need to charge the system back up with only water to start ensure there are no leaks present. If no leaks you can now turn on the chlorine valves then once again check for leaks. If no leaks are present you are now back to normal operations.



68.54  Employee Training

Employee training is always on going. When a problem occurs the operators that are on duty are there to fix it and the information is passed on to the next shift in case the problem happens again. All information is shared with all operators and sometimes if needed a step by step process is shown to ensure all operators are instructed on what to do if the problem happens to them. All repairs are logged into our maintenance records. When production slows in the winter months the operators attend continuing education classes provided by the state. 



68.56 (a) Maintenance 

All mechanical components of the chlorine system are checked in the fall of each year. Every year the plastic hoses from the cylinder to the valves are replaced as well as the valves themselves. This will also be added to our maintenance records.
